text: Job’s Final Defense
Then\f + \fr 29:1 \ft Hebrew “And” \f* Job again took up his discourse and said,
“⸤O that I were⸥\f + \fr 29:2 \ft Literally “Who shall give me” \f* as \add in\add* the months before,
as \add in\add* the days \add when\add* God watched over me,
when his shining lamp \add was\add* over my head—
by his light I walked through darkness—
as when I was in the days of my prime,
when God’s confiding \add was\add* over my ⸤house⸥,\f + \fr 29:4 \ft Literally “tent” \f*
when Shaddai\add was\add* still with me,
my children \add were\add* all around me,
when my paths were washed in sour milk,
and \add the\add* rock poured out streams of oil for me.
“At my going out \add the\add* gate to \add the\add* city,
I secured my seat in the square.
Young men saw me and stepped aside,
and \add the\add* aged rose up \add and\add* stood.
Officials refrained from talking,
and they laid \add their\add* hand on their mouth.
\add The\add* voices\f + \fr 29:10 \ft Hebrew “voice”; collective singular by context, governing a plural verb \f* of nobles were hushed,
and their tongue stuck to their palate.
“When \add the\add* ear heard and commended me,
and \add the\add* eye saw and testified in support of me
because I saved \add the\add* needy who cried for help,
and \add I saved\add*\f + \fr 29:12 \ft Supplying the elided verb from the preceding parallel line \f* \add the\add* orphan for whom \add there was\add* no helper.
\add The\add* blessing of \add the\add* wretched came upon me,
and I caused \add the\add* widow’s heart to sing for joy.
I put on righteousness, and it clothed me;
my justice \add was\add* like a robe and a headband.
“I was eyes to the blind,
and I \add was\add* feet to the lame.
I \add was\add* a father to the poor,
and I investigated ⸤the stranger’s⸥\f + \fr 29:16 \ft Literally “\fq the one \ft I knew not” \f* legal dispute.
And I broke \add the\add* evil one’s jaw bones,
and I made \add his\add* prey drop from his teeth.
“And I thought, ‘I will pass away in my nest,
and like the phoenix I shall multiply \add my\add* days.
My roots \add were\add* open to water,
and dew spent the night on my branches;
My glory \add was\add* new with me,
and ⸤I was revitalized regularly⸥.’\f + \fr 29:20 \ft See NJPS; literally “my bow in my hand was new” \f*
“They listened to me and waited,
and they kept silent for my counsel.
After my word, they did not speak again,
and my word dropped down \add like dew\add* upon them.
And they waited for me as \add for\add* the rain,
and they opened their mouth wide \add as\add* for \add the\add* spring rain.
I smiled for them \add when\add* they had no confidence \add in anything\add*,
and they did not extinguish the light of my face.
I chose their way, and I sat \add as\add* head,
and I dwelled like a king among the troops,
like \add one\add* who comforts mourners.
